title: Dental Health
question_text: Which of the following situations deal with sample proportions?

choices.text: Survey $10$ subjects, record how many brush their teeth daily.
Survey $10$ subjects, record the number of cavities they have.
Survey $10$ subjects, record the percent who brush their teeth daily.
Survey subjects until you have found one who does not brush their teeth daily.
None of the responses are correct since 10 subjects is too small a sample size for sample proportions.

solution:
Choice 'A' is incorrect; this deals with binomial probability since the question asks how many out of 10
brush their teeth daily.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; this deals with sample means since the number of cavities recorded is measured.

Choice 'C' is correct; this deals with a yes or no answer and records the percentage who brush their teeth daily.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; this selection deals with geometric probability where the variable of interest is number of trials until success.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; while a sample size of 10
for sample proportions is certainly not ideal, having a sample this small does not mean we are no longer dealing with sample proportions.
